articles.headline: When to Use a Mortgage Broker
articles.snippet: Shady practices of the past are haunting today’s brokers, to the point that some in the real estate industry refuse to do business with them.
articles.abstract: Shady practices of the past are haunting today’s brokers, to the point that some in the real estate industry refuse to do business with them.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s a bad time to be an honest mortgage broker.

articles.headline: Downturn Pushes More Toward Bankruptcy
articles.snippet: Filings for bankruptcy protection soared to the highest level since October 2005, when a federal law made bankruptcy more difficult and expensive.
articles.abstract: Filings for bankruptcy protection soared to the highest level since October 2005, when a federal law made bankruptcy more difficult and expensive.
articles.lead_paragraph: The ailing economy continues to pull more Americans into bankruptcy court, where the number of troubled consumers filing for protection soared in March to its highest level since October 2005, when a new law made it more arduous and expensive to file.

articles.headline: The Hand That Rocks the Cradle Can Call the Shots
articles.snippet: Some of India’s most successful businessmen, politicians and entertainers hear and heed their mothers’ advice daily.
articles.abstract: Some of India’s most successful businessmen, politicians and entertainers hear and heed their mothers’ advice daily.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI  When the Indian composer A. R. Rahman accepted two Oscars for his work on “Slumdog Millionaire,” he saved his most effusive thanks for his mother.

articles.headline: Google’s Plan for Out-of-Print Books Is Challenged
articles.snippet: A legal settlement giving Google online rights to out-of-print orphan books is being challenged in court.
articles.abstract: A legal settlement giving Google online rights to out-of-print orphan books is being challenged in court.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  The dusty stacks of the nation’s great university and research libraries are full of orphans  books that the author and publisher have essentially abandoned. They are out of print, and while they remain under copyright, the rights holders are unknown or cannot be found.

articles.headline: Big Bonuses at Fannie and Freddie Draw Fire
articles.snippet: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac are set to pay their employees “retention bonuses” totaling $210 million, despite calls from lawmakers to cancel the payments.
articles.abstract: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac are set to pay their employees “retention bonuses” totaling $210 million, despite calls from lawmakers to cancel the payments.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the two troubled companies at the heart of the nation’s mortgage market, are set to pay their employees “retention bonuses” totaling $210 million, despite calls from lawmakers to cancel the payments.

articles.headline: Empty Tables Threaten Some Restaurant Chains
articles.snippet: A steep drop in business has made some restaurant chains regret expanding so quickly before the recession.
articles.abstract: A steep drop in business has made some restaurant chains regret expanding so quickly before the recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: During a decade of easy credit and loose spending, American businesses built too many cars, houses, stores and factories. It turns out the country built too many restaurants, too.

articles.headline: Rejecting Aid, One Governor Irks His Own
articles.snippet: Mark Sanford’s threat to refuse more than $700 million in stimulus funds for South Carolina has put him on the national stage.
articles.abstract: Mark Sanford’s threat to refuse more than $700 million in stimulus funds for South Carolina has put him on the national stage.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C.  For a millionaire, Gov. Mark Sanford has a reputation for frugality that borders on the extreme.

articles.headline: Chinese Hunger for Sons Fuels Boys’ Abductions
articles.snippet: Parents in eastern industrial areas receive little help in finding their children, whose kidnappings constitute a thriving business.
articles.abstract: Parents in eastern industrial areas receive little help in finding their children, whose kidnappings constitute a thriving business.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHENZHEN, China — The thieves often strike at dusk, when children are playing outside and their parents are distracted by exhaustion.

articles.headline: Who Moved My Bonus? Executive Pay Makes a U-Turn
articles.snippet: Compensation for the highest-paid chief executives at public companies fell in 2008, largely dragged down by smaller bonuses.
articles.abstract: Compensation for the highest-paid chief executives at public companies fell in 2008, largely dragged down by smaller bonuses.
articles.lead_paragraph: BIG corporations, buffeted by widespread economic pain and heightened scrutiny of lush compensation packages, appear to be paying attention to a longstanding complaint from shareholders: When it comes to executive pay, greed  even the appearance of it  is not good.

articles.headline: Why Creditors Should Suffer, Too
articles.snippet: If we are going to prevent an A.I.G.-like debacle from happening again, institutions that engaged in bad deals need incentives to be more wary of their trading partners.
articles.abstract: If we are going to prevent an A.I.G.-like debacle from happening again, institutions that engaged in bad deals need incentives to be more wary of their trading partners.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE Obama administration’s proposals to reform financial regulation sound ambitious enough as they aim to bring companies like A.I.G. under a broader umbrella of government rule-making and scrutiny.

articles.headline: Executives Took, but the Directors Gave
articles.snippet: The corporate boards that approved steadily swelling paydays for C.E.O.’s are starting to come under scrutiny.
articles.abstract: The corporate boards that approved steadily swelling paydays for C.E.O.’s are starting to come under scrutiny.
articles.lead_paragraph: LITTLE of the ire against outsize C.E.O. paychecks has been aimed at the people who signed off on them: corporate directors.

articles.headline: Texas Mayor Caught in Deportation Furor
articles.snippet: Mayor Herbert A. Gears realized his own political future depended on how he navigated the treacherous terrain over immigration.
articles.abstract: Mayor Herbert A. Gears realized his own political future depended on how he navigated the treacherous terrain over immigration.
articles.lead_paragraph: IRVING, Tex. — Just after sunrise one morning last summer, as his two sons hurried out the door to school, Oscar Urbina might have presented a portrait of domestic stability in this Dallas suburb, a 35-year-old man with a nice home, a thriving family and a steady contracting job.

articles.headline: North Koreans Launch Rocket Over the Pacific
articles.snippet: Much of the world viewed the launching on Sunday as an effort by the North to prove that it is edging toward the capability to shoot a nuclear warhead on a longer-range missile.
articles.abstract: Much of the world viewed the launching on Sunday as an effort by the North to prove that it is edging toward the capability to shoot a nuclear warhead on a longer-range missile.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea defied the United States, China and a series of United Nations resolutions by launching a rocket on Sunday that the country said was designed to propel a satellite into space, but that much of the world viewed as an effort to prove it is edging toward the capability to shoot a nuclear warhead on a longer-range missile.
articles.byline: By Choe Sang-Hun and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: North Korean Missile Launch Was a Failure, Experts Say
articles.snippet: Some experts said the test undercut the North Korean campaign to come across as a fearsome adversary able to hurl deadly warheads halfway around the globe.
articles.abstract: Some experts said the test undercut the North Korean campaign to come across as a fearsome adversary able to hurl deadly warheads halfway around the globe.
articles.lead_paragraph: North Korea failed in its highly vaunted effort to fire a satellite into orbit, military and private experts said Sunday after reviewing detailed tracking data that showed the missile and payload fell into the sea. Some said the failure undercut the North Korean campaign to come across as a fearsome adversary able to hurl deadly warheads halfway around the globe.

articles.headline: Obama Seizes on Missile Launch in Seeking Nuclear Cuts
articles.snippet: Before a long-planned arms control speech in Prague, President Obama is confronted with North Korea’s missile test, and links that country’s defiance with the need for nonproliferation.
articles.abstract: Before a long-planned arms control speech in Prague, President Obama is confronted with North Korea’s missile test, and links that country’s defiance with the need for nonproliferation.
articles.lead_paragraph: PRAGUE — Hours after North Korea’s missile test, President Obama on Sunday called for new United Nations sanctions and laid out a new approach to American nuclear disarmament policy — one intended to strengthen the United States and its allies in halting proliferation.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: I.B.M. Withdraws $7 Billion Offer for Sun
articles.snippet: I.B.M. dropped its bid after Sun’s board balked at a reduced offer and I.B.M. resisted other conditions, said people close to the talks.
articles.abstract: I.B.M. dropped its bid after Sun’s board balked at a reduced offer and I.B.M. resisted other conditions, said people close to the talks.
articles.lead_paragraph: I.B.M. withdrew its $7 billion bid for Sun Microsystems on Sunday, one day after Sun’s board balked at a reduced offer, according to three people close to the talks.
articles.byline: By Steve Lohr and Ashlee Vance

articles.headline: Time Is Short as U.S. Presses a Reluctant Pakistan
articles.snippet: In seeking an alliance with Pakistan against militants, America is courting a Muslim nation whose military is fixated on India.
articles.abstract: In seeking an alliance with Pakistan against militants, America is courting a Muslim nation whose military is fixated on India.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  President Obama’s strategy of offering Pakistan a partnership to defeat the insurgency here calls for a virtual remaking of this nation’s institutions and even of the national psyche, an ambitious agenda that Pakistan’s politicians and people appear unprepared to take up.

articles.headline: A Disaster Still Raw, Years Later
articles.snippet: “Treme,” an HBO series by David Simon, tells the story of New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina. The series is separated by just enough time to offer insight without being overly detached.
articles.abstract: “Treme,” an HBO series by David Simon, tells the story of New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina. The series is separated by just enough time to offer insight without being overly detached.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS

articles.headline: Some Revile Plan to Limit Short-Selling
articles.snippet: Regulators are drafting rules to restrict short-selling, or trades that profit from a decline in a stock’s price.
articles.abstract: Regulators are drafting rules to restrict short-selling, or trades that profit from a decline in a stock’s price.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Responding to the depressed financial markets, regulators for the second time in less than a week are preparing to take steps that could have the effect of temporarily shoring up stock prices. But in the process, some critics say, the measures could undermine the integrity of the markets.

articles.headline: Pixar’s Art Leaves Profit Watchers Edgy
articles.snippet: “Up,” the latest film from Pixar Animation Studios, is expected to be a critical and commercial success, but Wall Street has its doubts.
articles.abstract: “Up,” the latest film from Pixar Animation Studios, is expected to be a critical and commercial success, but Wall Street has its doubts.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Pixar Animation Studios has never released a movie that was not a commercial and creative triumph, and its 10th feature, “Up,” is looking to be no exception  at least artistically.

articles.headline: Obama’s Top Auto Industry Troubleshooter
articles.snippet: Steven Rattner, a well-known media banker, is playing a crucial role for Washington as he advises the Detroit automakers on their overhauls.
articles.abstract: Steven Rattner, a well-known media banker, is playing a crucial role for Washington as he advises the Detroit automakers on their overhauls.
articles.lead_paragraph: After 26 years as one of the most politically connected investment bankers on Wall Street, Steven Rattner finally took a job in Washington  only it is not quite the one friends and business associates thought it would be.

articles.headline: Micro-Billing, Byte by Byte, Suits the World of Cellphones
articles.snippet: The digital marketplace has strained many in the media realm, but one industry has thrived: the phone companies, which make sure not to give away entertainment.
articles.abstract: The digital marketplace has strained many in the media realm, but one industry has thrived: the phone companies, which make sure not to give away entertainment.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS  As the music, film, television, newspaper, book and video-game industries strain to find a way to thrive in the new digital marketplace, one seems to have figured it all out.
articles.byline: By Matt Richtel and Bob Tedeschi

articles.headline: A Rich Education for Summers (After Harvard)
articles.snippet: After leaving Harvard, Lawrence H. Summers earned nearly $5.2 million advising elite math wizards and scientists at a New York hedge fund.
articles.abstract: After leaving Harvard, Lawrence H. Summers earned nearly $5.2 million advising elite math wizards and scientists at a New York hedge fund.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lawrence H. Summers plays down his stint in the hedge fund business as a mere part-time job  but the financial and intellectual rewards that he gained there would make even most full-time workers envious.

articles.headline: South Africa Drops Charges Against Leading Presidential Contender
articles.snippet: The withdrawal of charges against Jacob Zuma, the man likely to become South Africa’s next president, will further polarize the nation.
articles.abstract: The withdrawal of charges against Jacob Zuma, the man likely to become South Africa’s next president, will further polarize the nation.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG  Corruption charges against Jacob Zuma  the man almost certain to become South Africa’s president after elections later this month  were dropped Monday by prosecutors who said the case had been tainted by a tawdry, secret manipulation of the legal process from within their own ranks.

articles.headline: America Seeks Bonds to Islam, Obama Insists
articles.snippet: President Obama said that U.S. relations with the Islamic world will not center on fighting Al Qaeda.
articles.abstract: President Obama said that U.S. relations with the Islamic world will not center on fighting Al Qaeda.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANKARA, Turkey  President Obama formally began his outreach to the Muslim world on Monday when he spoke before Turkey’s Parliament, telling legislators that the United States “is not and will never be at war with Islam.”

articles.headline: Cuomo Sues Over Madoff Investments
articles.snippet: The New York attorney general has accused J. Ezra Merkin, whose clients lost more than $2 billion, of fraud and deception.
articles.abstract: The New York attorney general has accused J. Ezra Merkin, whose clients lost more than $2 billion, of fraud and deception.
articles.lead_paragraph: J. Ezra Merkin, a prominent New York financier and philanthropist, was never the savvy investor he seemed to be — even before he steered more than $2 billion of his clients’ money into Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme, according to a civil lawsuit filed on Monday.
